Description.val: This line item funds modifications to Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) products used on multiple platforms.   Modifications budgeted and programmed include: procurement and enhancement of Low Band Transmitter Antenna Group inventory, AN/ALQ-99 Tactical Jamming System upgrades and related sustainability, capability, and viability modifications,  Airborne Electronic Attack Expendable upgrades and integration, and Area Chaff Dispenser (ALE-43) upgrades and integration. AEA will support procurement of new technologies and equipment as needed to combat emerging electronic warfare technology and systems.

Justification.val:
The Department of the Navy has been tasked with accomplishing the Nation's Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) mission in various theaters of operation over the last few decades.  The AEA capability fielded by the Navy on the EA-6B Prowler has been a high demand, low density asset.  The Navy and Marine Corps are transitioning away from the EA-6B Prowler aircraft; the Navy is transitioning to the EA-18G Growler aircraft and the Marine Corps is transitioning to an organic capability utilizing electronic warfare payloads flown on Marine Corps aircraft.  Stable investment in AEA systems will ensure continued availability of AEA capability to meet warfighter demand.  Investment in the ALQ-99 Tactical Jamming System will ensure continued system availability until Next Generation Jammer Full Operational Capability.  Modifications to ALE-43 are required to transition the Bulk Chaff capability from the EA-6B Prowler platform to the F/A-18E/F platform.  

Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) System procurements and related efforts are required to combat emerging electronic warfare technology and systems.  Investment in AEA System efforts will ensure that sufficient AEA capability is available to meet warfighter requirements.

In FY14, the Area Chaff Dispenser (ALE-43) program was moved from OSIP 007-11 to OSIP 012-14.

Name.@footnote: Data cost growth in excess of approved OSD inflation indices is due to increased data requirements as a result of increased non-recurring engineering efforts.
Cost growth in excess of approved OSD inflation indices is due to procurement of re-engineered support equipment.
ILS cost growth in excess of approved OSD indices is due to increased requirements due to Band 4 and Band 5/6 obsolescence mitigation.
Other support cost growth in excess of approved OSD inflation indices is due to phasing of obsolescence mitigation efforts in FY14.
Extended Low Band Radome (GELBR) unit cost growth in excess of OSD approved indices in FY 2014 and FY 2018 is due to decreased quantities and step-ladder pricing of the firm fixed price contract.
Low Band Transmitter unit cost growth in excess of OSD approved indicies in FY14 is due to decreased quantities and step-ladder pricing of the firm fixed price contract.

Installation Equipment N/R growth from FY 2013 to FY 2014 in excess of approved OSD inflation indicies is due to engineering effort required to commence production of Hardbacks and Band 5/6 Transmitters in FY 2014.

Description.val:
The Extended Low Band Radome currently flown on the EA-6B is structurally incompatible with the EA-18G.  Production of compatible EA-18G Extended Low Band Radomes is required for integration of the ALQ-99 onto the EA-18G.  Price growth in excess of OSD approved indicies in FY14 is due to decreased quantity and step-ladder pricing of the firm fixed price contracts.

The Band 5/6 Transmitter inventory has historically remained below inventory objective level.  Reconstitution of reclaimed United States Air Force (USAF) EF-111 Band 5/6 transmitters to United States Navy (USN) configuration will alleviate significant inventory shortfall for EA-6B and EA-18G platforms.

The ALQ-99 Hardbacks that are currently in inventory are reaching their fatigue life limits.  In order to preserve ALQ-99 Tactical Jamming System (TJS) availability, investments in new Hardbacks are required.

INSTALLATION EQUIPMENT N/R:  ALQ-99 TJS obsolescence mitigation efforts, capability enhancements and reliability enhancements require non-recurring engineering for ALQ-99 TJS components such as the Hardback, the Universal Exciter Upgrade, LBT AG, Band 4 Transmitters, Band 5/6 Transmitters, Band 9/10 Transmitters, and Bands 7-8 Transmitters.  Additionally, funds will provide for the re-engineering of depot support equipment in order to resolve ALQ-99 readiness degraders.

ENGINEERING CHANGES: This Operational and Safety Improvement Program covers system modifications required to improve ALQ-99 reliability, maintainability, availability, resolve obsolescence issues, and correct deficiencies found in testing or in the field.  Engineering changes are needed to enhance mission capability and integration of evolving Electronic Warfare systems, including the Area Chaff Dispenser (ALE-43), to address increased mission requirements and emerging threats in support of EA-6B, EA-18G, FA-18 Series, AV-8B, and rotary aircraft.  
 
SUPPORT EQUIPMENT: Introduction of new/modified ALQ-99 pod equipment requires new/modified organizational, intermediate, and depot level support equipment; such as modifications and additions to the ALQ-99 pod test set to support LBT AG and modifications to the High Power Device Test Set to extend frequency coverage to test Band 9/10 transmitters.  Required changes to existing support equipment will improve reliability, maintainability, availability, address obsolescence issues, and correct deficiencies found in testing or in the field.

In FY14, the Area Chaff Dispenser (ALE-43) program was moved from OSIP 007-11 to OSIP 012-14.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Following a competitive acquisition and Milestone II approval, Engineering and Manufacturing Prototype and Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) testing conducted at government and contractor facilities successfully demonstrated the key performance parameters identified in Office of the Chief of Naval Operations/N88 ltr Ser No. N880C3/6S663399 of 26 JUL 96 can be attained with the present Low Band Transmitter (LBT) design. LRIP unit Testing began in April 2007, Milestone III was achieved in April 2008 and a Full Rate Production contract was awarded June 2008.  In response to the increasing force protection requirement, an Early Operational Capability for LBT was met in August 2006.

The ALE-43 Chaff Dispenser is the sole Area Chaff Dispenser approved for United States Navy and United States Marine Corps tactical aircraft.  The current ALE-43 chaff dispenser, qualified on EA-6B and F/A-18C/D, requires form factor and control interface modifications to remain available for fleet usage due to the fleet migration to a common tactical airframe in the F/A-18 E/F.  Modifications include a form factor change into a current F/A-18E/F approved pod shape such as the AN/ASD-12 Shared Reconnaissance Pod and pod level Operational Flight Program changes.  Associated internal structural and service modifications are also required.  Capability, flexibility, and adaptability will improve via control interface and chaff cutter mechanism improvements.

INSTALLATION EQUIPMENT N/R: Non-recurring engineering efforts are required in order to ensure proper integration of the ALE-43 pod onto the F/A-18 E/F platform.

SUPPORT EQUIPMENT: Introduction of new/modified Area Chaff Dispensing equipment requires new/modified organizational, intermediate and depot level support equipment.   Changes to existing support equipment will be needed to improve reliability, maintainability, availability, address obsolescence issues, and correct deficiencies found in testing or in the field.

ENGINEERING CHANGES: This Area Chaff Dispensing Program covers system modifications required to improve reliability, maintainability, availability, enhance mission capability, interface and integrate with evolving Electronic Attack systems, resolve obsolescence issues, and correct deficiencies found in testing or in the field.

In FY14, the Area Chaff Dispenser (ALE-43) program was moved to OSIP 012-14 from OSIP 007-11.
